body: The simple-prompt option doesn't support multi-line input, but I thought Emacs 'inferior-shell' magic was working round that. @tacaswell ?
In ansi-term ipython work well, but I need REPL. Standart python interactive shell works fine, but I really miss %magic%
FYI: prompt_toolkit 1.0.4 has been released today, it has one improvement that should make prompt_toolkit render at least slightly better in emacs-term. Can you have a try?

In the context of IPython,  that means try without `--simple-prompt`, so that it uses prompt_toolkit.

@tacaswell might also be interested in testing.

Hello, I have updated to prompt_toolkit 1.0.4 with emacs 25.0.95.1 and ipython 5.0.0. For some reason, running just ipython defaults to the simple-prompt and I am having trouble testing with prompt_toolkit - which is weird and I cannot figure out why.

However, running `jupyter console` still returns the same error it was returning before updating prompt_toolkit. Not sure if this helps or just confuses things further.

Here is the traceback

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\Scripts\jupyter-console-script.py", line 5, in <module>
    sys.exit(jupyter_console.app.main())
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\jupyter_core\application.py", line 267, in launch_instance
    return super(JupyterApp, cls).launch_instance(argv=argv, **kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\traitlets\config\application.py", line 595, in launch_instance
    app.initialize(argv)
  File "<decorator-gen-114>", line 2, in initialize
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\traitlets\config\application.py", line 74, in catch_config_error
    return method(app, *args, **kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\jupyter_console\app.py", line 137, in initialize
    self.init_shell()
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\jupyter_console\app.py", line 110, in init_shell
    client=self.kernel_client,
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\traitlets\config\configurable.py", line 412, in instance
    inst = cls(*args, **kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\jupyter_console\ptshell.py", line 252, in __init__
    self.init_prompt_toolkit_cli()
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\jupyter_console\ptshell.py", line 404, in init_prompt_toolkit_cli
    self.pt_cli = CommandLineInterface(app, eventloop=self._eventloop)
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\prompt_toolkit\interface.py", line 80, in __init__
    self.output = output or create_output()
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\prompt_toolkit\shortcuts.py", line 114, in create_output
    return Win32Output(stdout)
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\prompt_toolkit\terminal\win32_output.py", line 80, in __init__
    info = self.get_win32_screen_buffer_info()
  File "C:\Users\A6419643\AppData\Local\Continuum\Miniconda3\lib\site-packages\prompt_toolkit\terminal\win32_output.py", line 150, in get_win32_screen_buffer_info
    raise NoConsoleScreenBufferError
prompt_toolkit.terminal.win32_output.NoConsoleScreenBufferError: No Windows console found. Are you running cmd.exe?

Process Python exited abnormally with code 1

```

I'd guess that maybe our checks for a terminal fail, so it falls back to simple-prompt automatically.

@jonathanslenders - I take it that traceback is not what you were expecting! Is there anything else the Windows+Emacs users should try?
Any progress on this issue?

Sorry, I missed the ping on this in July.

In comint mode you only get one line, but you can use one of the `send-buffer-to-shell` commands in python-mode / elpy to send a buffer to the interpreter.  That plus an org-mode source region or just a `/tmp/scratch.py` file is how I do multi-line editing these days.

This is pretty huge for us Emacs users. :(

Why does it work on iPython 4.x? What changed exactly?

@AndreaOrru Pretty sure the change is moving from readline to prompt toolkit which lots some of the special-cased work arounds on both sides.

I strongly suggest opening `/tmp/scratch.py`, writing your multi-line stuff there (or using org-mode + source blocks), and shipping it to the shell via `send-buffer-to-shell` (bound to `C-c C-c` by elpy).

Hi guys,

I have the following problem using Emacs25 with ipython 5, as it uses some strange colours. I have this as walk-around

```
(setq python-shell-interpreter "ipython" python-shell-interpreter-args "--simple-prompt -i")
```

but then I get this error as in reported bug

```
SyntaxError: unexpected EOF while parsing
```

whenever I try to send multiline code ending with ':' character. Sending whole buffer works just fine but individual lines are problematic, which makes testing code very difficult.

Please help.

hi @mashu,

the work around you use above makes the ipython prompt work in emacs, but it does not allow multiline editing. There is currently no solution that allows multiline editing in an ipython shell in emacs.

If you want multiline editing, I would follow @tacaswell's advice above using python buffers, etc.

So why you couldn\`t have both readline and promt_toolkit and switching them using some flags? Even if you won\`t support readline you can at least leave it as it is. This is huge regression for many users and I don\`t think promt_toolkit is much better then readline. It isn`t work with ipdb also.
@mashu I installed ipython 4.2.1 and won`t update it until multiline in emacs will not fixed.

@Crandel indeed downgrading to ipython 4.2.1 is a way better solution! 
All works as expected with Emacs+ipython 4.x

Quick command for people in a hurry

```
pip install --force-reinstall ipython==4.2.1
```

And as @Crandel suggested option for readline support on ipython side would be nice for other projects, not only Emacs community. Hope you guys consider this!

> option for readline support on ipython side would be nice for other projects, not only Emacs community.

Sorry we hit your workflow, but one of the motivations behind switching to prompt_toolkit was that we could get rid of a whole lot of code that was supporting the readline interface. I don't see us adding that back.

What other projects are affected? So far, Emacs inferior shell is the only thing where I've heard of problems with the new interface.

I have a similar problem with a relatively unique vi+tmux+slimux+ipython workflow. I use tmux to open up a vi pane, and an ipython pane, and slimux lets me use a key combo in vi to send a line--or block of text--to the ipython interpreter to be executed. Very nice: the lines sent from vi go into an [In] prompt, and the output is in an [Out] prompt.

With the "upgrade" to iPython 5, I can no longer send a block of code via slimux. If I want to send a loop or function definition, I have to send them line-by-line. Granted, it works that way, but sending over a block of text is _way_ easier. I haven't been able to find a work-around, and am about to go back to iPython 4.x.

Do you know how those lines are being sent to IPython? Just sending them with newlines between them should work, and if you can get that machinery to use the [bracketed paste](https://cirw.in/blog/bracketed-paste) mechanism, it should be even better.

I don't know any `vimscript`, and have no desire to learn, but digging into `slimux.vim`, this is what I can make out as relevant:

``` vimscript
command! SlimuxREPLSendLine call SlimuxSendCode(getline(".") . "\n")
command! -range=% -bar -nargs=* SlimuxREPLSendSelection call SlimuxSendCode(s:GetVisual())
```

It looks like SendLine sends a newline after the line of code, but GetVisual() doesn't necessarily insert extra newlines? I suppose I can try modifying the function GetVisual to insert newlines or something (there are already newlines in the selection, though...).

But one of the nice things about Slimux is that it's agnostic as far as the REPL goes. All it does is send selected text from one tmux pane to another. So the exact same setup works for bash, etc.

And what do you see when you do try to send a block of code to IPython? I don't know vimscript either, but there's nothing obviously wrong with that.

If you're willing to try debugging, could you run [this script](https://github.com/pexpect/pexpect/blob/master/tests/getch.py) in the terminal part and send a multiline block to it? It should show the bytes that are sent to the terminal. Then you can use Ctrl-Space to quit it.

Thanks for taking a look at this. I know I'm just presenting a wish list, hoping that other people will make what I want.

Anyway, here are a couple examples.

In my code file (vim):

``` python
walrus_parts = ['blubber', 'flipper']                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
walrus_locations = {'ET': 'Point Defiance', 'Antje': 'Tierpark Hagenbeck'}
```

when I send this to iPython 5, I get:

``` python
In [9]: walrus_parts = ['blubber', 'flipper']                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   

In [10]: walrus_locations                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                                                                                                                                                                     
NameError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)                                                                                                                                                                                                     
<ipython-input-10-ea59699135df> in <module>()                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
----> 1 walrus_locations                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        

NameError: name 'walrus_locations' is not defined
```

If I send:

``` python
walruses = ['Jocko', 'Antje', 'ET']                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
for walrus in walruses:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
    print walrus 
```

I get:

``` python
In [12]: walruses = ['Jocko', 'Antje', 'ET']
```

If I just send the `for` loop (and now `walruses` has been defined):

``` python
In [13]: for walrus in walruses:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
    ...:         print walrus                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
  File "<ipython-input-13-a3d3c22573d1>", line 2                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
    print walrus                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
               ^                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

In contrast, in iPython 4.x I get:

``` python
In [1]: walruses = ['Jocko', 'Antje', 'ET']                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     

In [2]: for walrus in walruses:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
   ...:         print walrus                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    
   ...:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
Jocko                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
Antje                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
ET
```

It looks to me like iPython 5 treats the first line differently from subsequent lines. In the non-loop block, it _only_ executed the first line.

Running the function you gave me (I skipped the shebang and comments). (And when I say "running", I mean my REPL setup, sending from vi to iPython 5 using slimux.)

``` python
In [5]: from __future__ import print_function                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   

In [6]:   break                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
  File "<ipython-input-6-b20fcc2397e7>", line 1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
    break                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
SyntaxError: 'break' outside loop
```

Hope that helps. Happy to try and clarify anything.

That's confusing...

For the script I linked to above, I mean: get that script running in the terminal by a means that works (like `python getch.py`), and then send text to that terminal as you would with IPython. The script is designed to show the raw bytes that it's receiving, which should help us work out what's going on.

Oh, I see. I ran `getch.py` in one tmux pane, and sent over the following code via slimux. (This is one of the same walrus examples as before.)

If you'd like other pieces of code, happy to do it. I figured this was long enough for one post.

``` python
walrus_parts = ['blubber', 'flipper']                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
walrus_locations = {'ET': 'Point Defiance', 'Antje': 'Tierpark Hagenbeck'}
```

``` python
In [2]: prompt_toolkit.__version__
Out[2]: '1.0.7'
```

So I guess it's 0.0.1 out-of-date. I don't have a lot of control of the Python libraries on the system, as I'm on a large cluster (TACC). If you think it would make a difference, I could try installing 1.0.8 locally, and rearranging my PYTHONPATH so my local library takes precedence?

I don't think that would be it - I think the CR->LF conversion has been there a while. If you've got time to fiddle with it then go for it, otherwise let's see what Jonathan (the author of prompt_toolkit) thinks.

Like Crandel I downgraded to ipython4 because of the lack of multi-line support when running ipython in emacs repl. I tried to use the EIN emacs mode and that works fine with ipython5 although tabs don't work well. Also the notebook flow slows me down so It would be great if someone could add multi-line support with emacs in ipython5 : ). I don't see myself abandoning emacs just yet ;-)

Hi @usnigg, not to get sidetracked here, but does your Emacs Python REPL show the input commands in the interpreter? I like my vi setup, but I've been playing with Emacs, and one thing that annoys me about the Python major mode and associated inferior process is that it only displays things that I explicitly ask it to print, not the input. For my work I execute a lot of lines or code blocks individually, and seeing the command displayed in the interpreter helps keep track of what's going on.

@bennigoetz. No it doesn't at least with C-c | (execute region). I rarely use that though. If I needed to see the input I'd just select and copy the lines of code into the ipython buffer and execute, which works with multi-line support.
